column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=She took Rastignac ’s arm , and went towards a sofa in the card-room .
#Text=“ I want you to go to the Marquis , ” she said .
#Text=“ Jacques , my footman , will go with you ; he has a letter that you will take .
#Text=I am asking the Marquis to give my letters back to me .
#Text=He will give them all up , I like to think that .
#Text=When you have my letters , go up to my room with them .
#Text=Some one shall bring me word . ”
#Text=She rose to go to meet the Duchesse de Langeais , her most intimate friend , who had come like the rest of the world .
#Text=Rastignac went .
#Text=He asked for the Marquis d’Ajuda at the Hotel Rochefide , feeling certain that the latter would be spending his evening there , and so it proved .
#Text=The Marquis went to his own house with Rastignac , and gave a casket to the student , saying as he did so , “ They are all there . ”

#Text=He seemed as if he was about to say something to Eugene , to ask about the ball , or the Vicomtesse ; perhaps he was on the brink of the confession that , even then , he was in despair , and knew that his marriage had been a fatal mistake ; but a proud gleam shone in his eyes , and with deplorable courage he kept his noblest feelings a secret .
#Text=“ Do not even mention my name to her , my dear Eugene . ”
#Text=He grasped Rastignac ’s hand sadly and affectionately , and turned away from him .
#Text=Eugene went back to the Hotel Beauseant , the servant took him to the Vicomtesse ’s room .
#Text=There were signs there of preparations for a journey .
#Text=He sat down by the fire , fixed his eyes on the cedar wood casket , and fell into deep mournful musings .
#Text=Mme . de Beauseant loomed large in these imaginings , like a goddess in the Iliad .
#Text=“ Ah ! my friend ! ... ” said the Vicomtesse ; she crossed the room and laid her hand on Rastignac ’s shoulder .
#Text=He saw the tears in his cousin ’s uplifted eyes , saw that one hand was raised to take the casket , and that the fingers of the other trembled .
#Text=Suddenly she took the casket , put it in the fire , and watched it burn .
#Text=“ They are dancing , ” she said .
#Text=“ They all came very early ; but death will be long in coming .
#Text=Hush !
#Text=my friend , ” and she laid a finger on Rastignac ’s lips , seeing that he was about to speak .
#Text=“ I shall never see Paris again .
#Text=I am taking my leave of the world .
#Text=At five o’clock this morning I shall set out on my journey ; I mean to bury myself in the remotest part of Normandy .

#Text=I have had very little time to make my arrangements ; since three o’clock this afternoon I have been busy signing documents , setting my affairs in order ; there was no one whom I could send to ... ”
#Text=She broke off .
#Text=“ He was sure to be ... ”
#Text=Again she broke off ; the weight of her sorrow was more than she could bear .
#Text=In such moments as these everything is agony , and some words are impossible to utter .
#Text=“ And so I counted upon you to do me this last piece of service this evening , ” she said .
#Text=“ I should like to give you some pledge of friendship .
#Text=I shall often think of you .
#Text=You have seemed to me to be kind and noble , fresh-hearted and true , in this world where such qualities are seldom found .
#Text=I should like you to think sometimes of me .
#Text=Stay , ” she said , glancing about her , “ there is this box that has held my gloves .

#Text=Every time I opened it before going to a ball or to the theatre , I used to feel that I must be beautiful , because I was so happy ; and I never touched it except to lay some gracious memory in it :
#Text=there is so much of my old self in it , of a Madame de Beauseant who now lives no longer .
#Text=Will you take it ?
#Text=I will leave directions that it is to be sent to you in the Rue d’Artois . --
#Text=Mme . de Nucingen looked very charming this evening .
#Text=Eugene , you must love her .
#Text=Perhaps we may never see each other again , my friend ; but be sure of this , that I shall pray for you who have been kind to me . --
#Text=Now , let us go downstairs .
#Text=People shall not think that I am weeping .
#Text=I have all time and eternity before me , and where I am going I shall be alone , and no one will ask me the reason of my tears .
#Text=One last look round first . ”
#Text=She stood for a moment .
#Text=Then she covered her eyes with her hands for an instant , dashed away the tears , bathed her face with cold water , and took the student ’s arm .
#Text=“ Let us go ! ” she said .
#Text=This suffering , endured with such noble fortitude , shook Eugene with a more violent emotion than he had felt before .
#Text=They went back to the ballroom , and Mme . de Beauseant went through the rooms on Eugene ’s arm -- the last delicately gracious act of a gracious woman .
#Text=In another moment he saw the sisters , Mme . de Restaud and Mme . de Nucingen .
#Text=The Countess shone in all the glory of her magnificent diamonds ; every stone must have scorched like fire , she was never to wear them again .
#Text=Strong as love and pride might be in her , she found it difficult to meet her husband ’s eyes .
#Text=The sight of her was scarcely calculated to lighten Rastignac ’s sad thoughts ; through the blaze of those diamonds he seemed to see the wretched pallet-bed on which Father Goriot was lying .
#Text=The Vicomtesse misread his melancholy ; she withdrew her hand from his arm .
